required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Effect of Soy on Cognition and Hot Flashes in Men With Prostate Cancer Undergoing Testosterone Suppression Therapy
clinical_study.official_title: Effect of Isoflavones on Cognition, Quality of Life and Hot Flashes in Men With Prostate Cancer Undergoing Androgen Deprivation Therapy

brief_summary.textblock: This study will look at the effects of a soy supplement called Revival on memory, quality of life, and hot flashes in men with prostate cancer who are being treated with testosterone suppression therapy. Hypothesis: Treating men who have prostate CA with daily Revival will result in at least a 50% reduction in hot flashes compared to placebo.

detailed_description.textblock: This research study will look at the effects of a soy supplement called Revival on memory, quality of life, and hot flashes in men with prostate cancer who are undergoing (ADT) androgen deprivation therapy. Participants will be given either placebo or Revival. Participants will be asked to take their supplement once/day for 14 weeks.Blood will be drawn to check on liver, kidney, thyroid, cholesterol,and prostate health. Urine will be collected to check on bone markers. Patients will be asked to complete questionnaires to test memory, attention span, and vocabulary.Possible benefits may include increase in memory, decrease in hot flashes, and a general increase in quality of life.

primary_outcome.measure: Cognitive Function as Assessed by the National Adult Reading Test (NART)
primary_outcome.description: the NART estimates intelligence levels of English-speaking patients. It consists of 50 short words with irregular spelling or phonetic appearance which the participant must read and pronounce. The higher the score, the higher number of correct responses. Scores are 0-50.

primary_outcome.measure: Cognitive Function as Assessed by the Hopkins Verbal Learning Test (HVLT), Total Recall Score
primary_outcome.description: The test consists 12 nouns, four words each from one of three semantic categories (e.g., precious gems, articles of clothing, vegetables, etc.), to be learned over the course of three learning trials. Approximately 20-25 min later, a delayed recall trial and a recognition trial are completed. The delayed recall requires free recall of any words remembered. The recognition trial is composed of 24 words, including the 12 target words and 12 false-positives, 6 semantically related, & 6 semantically unrelated. When scoring the HVLT, the three learning trials are combined to calculate a total recall score (0-36); the delayed recall trial creates the delayed recall score ( -12) ; the retention (%) score (0-100%) is calculated by dividing the delayed recall trial by the higher of learning trial 2 or 3; and the recognition discrimination index is comprised by subtracting the total number of false positives from the total number of true positives. A higher score = higher cognition.

primary_outcome.measure: Cognitive Function as Assessed by the Hopkins Verbal Learning Test (HVLT), Recognition Discrimination Index
primary_outcome.description: The test consists 12 nouns, four words each from one of three semantic categories (e.g., precious gems, articles of clothing, vegetables, etc.), to be learned over the course of three learning trials. Approximately 20-25 min later, a delayed recall trial and a recognition trial are completed. The delayed recall requires free recall of any words remembered. The recognition trial is composed of 24 words, including the 12 target words and 12 false-positives, 6 semantically related, & 6 semantically unrelated. When scoring the HVLT, the three learning trials are combined to calculate a total recall score (0-36); the delayed recall trial creates the delayed recall score ( -12) ; the retention (%) score (0-100%) is calculated by dividing the delayed recall trial by the higher of learning trial 2 or 3; and the recognition discrimination index is comprised by subtracting the total number of false positives from the total number of true positives. A higher score= higher cognitive function.

primary_outcome.measure: Cognitive Function as Assessed by the Hopkins Verbal Learning Test (HVLT), Percent Retained
primary_outcome.description: The test consists 12 nouns, four words each from one of three semantic categories (e.g., precious gems, articles of clothing, vegetables, etc.), to be learned over the course of three learning trials. Approximately 20-25 min later, a delayed recall trial and a recognition trial are completed. The delayed recall requires free recall of any words remembered. The recognition trial is composed of 24 words, including the 12 target words and 12 false-positives, 6 semantically related, and 6 semantically unrelated. When scoring the HVLT, the three learning trials are combined to calculate a total recall score (0-36); the delayed recall trial creates the delayed recall score ( -12) ; the retention (%) score (0-100%) is calculated by dividing the delayed recall trial by the higher of learning trial 2 or 3; and the recognition discrimination index is comprised by subtracting the total number of false positives from the total number of true positives.A higher score= higher cognitive function.

primary_outcome.measure: Cognitive Function as Assessed by the F-A-S Test
primary_outcome.description: The F-A-S Test, a subtest of the Neurosensory Center Comprehensive Examination for Aphasia (NCCEA), is a measure of phonemic word fluency, which is a type of verbal fluency. It assesses phonemic fluency by requesting an individual to orally produce as many words as possible that begin with the letters F, A, and S within a prescribed time frame (1 minute)

primary_outcome.measure: Cognition as Assessed by the Grooved Pegboard Test (GPT) , Dominant Hand Time (Seconds)
primary_outcome.description: The GPT assesses eye-hand coordination and motor speed and thus requires sensory motor integration and a high level of motor processing. The test apparatus consists of a square metal surface (10.1 cm2) with a 5 × 5 matrix of keyhole shaped holes in various orientations. The task requires the examinee to pick up the keyhole shaped peg (3 mm in diameter) individually from the well just above the 5 × 5 matrix of holes from left to right and top to bottom as quickly as possible using the dominant hand. Because the holes are in various orientations, examinees must manipulate each peg in their hand (usually between the index finger and thumb) so that the peg aligns with the orientation of the hole. A faster time, indicates greater cognitive functioning.

primary_outcome.measure: Cognition as Assessed by the Grooved Pegboard Test (GPT) , Non-dominant Hand Time (Seconds)
primary_outcome.description: The GPT assesses eye-hand coordination and motor speed and thus requires sensory motor integration and a high level of motor processing. The test apparatus consists of a square metal surface (10.1 cm2) with a 5 × 5 matrix of keyhole shaped holes in various orientations. The task requires the examinee to pick up the keyhole shaped peg (3 mm in diameter) individually from the well just above the 5 × 5 matrix of holes from left to right and top to bottom as quickly as possible using the non-dominant hand. Because the holes are in various orientations, examinees must manipulate each peg in their hand (usually between the index finger and thumb) so that the peg aligns with the orientation of the hole.

primary_outcome.measure: Cognition as Assessed by the Grooved Pegboard Test (GPT) , Number of Dominant Hand Drops
primary_outcome.description: The GPT assesses eye-hand coordination and motor speed and thus requires sensory motor integration and a high level of motor processing. The test apparatus consists of a square metal surface (10.1 cm2) with a 5 × 5 matrix of keyhole shaped holes in various orientations. The task requires the examinee to pick up the keyhole shaped peg (3 mm in diameter) individually from the well just above the 5 × 5 matrix of holes from left to right and top to bottom as quickly as possible using the dominant hand. Because the holes are in various orientations, examinees must manipulate each peg in their hand (usually between the index finger and thumb) so that the peg aligns with the orientation of the hole.

primary_outcome.measure: Cognition as Assessed by the Grooved Pegboard Test (GPT) , Number of Non- Dominant Hand Drops
primary_outcome.description: The GPT assesses eye-hand coordination and motor speed and thus requires sensory motor integration and a high level of motor processing. The test apparatus consists of a square metal surface (10.1 cm2) with a 5 × 5 matrix of keyhole shaped holes in various orientations. The task requires the examinee to pick up the keyhole shaped peg (3 mm in diameter) individually from the well just above the 5 × 5 matrix of holes from left to right and top to bottom as quickly as possible using the dominant hand. Because the holes are in various orientations, examinees must manipulate each peg in their hand (usually between the index finger and thumb) so that the peg aligns with the orientation of the hole.

primary_outcome.measure: Cognition as Assessed by the Rex Complex Figure Test (RCFT), Immediate Recall
primary_outcome.description: The test measures recognition memory for the elements of the Rey complex figure, and assesses the respondent's ability to use cues to retrieve information. Scoring of drawings is based on the widely used 36-point scoring system. Each of the 18 scoring units is scored based on accuracy and placement criteria. Items of the figure can earn points: Correct Image: placed properly (2 points), placed poorly (1 point) Distorted or Incomplete Image, but recognizable: placed properly (1 point), placed poorly (1/2) point Absent or not recognizable: 0 points Scale ranges 0-36. with 36 being greatest cognitive function.

primary_outcome.measure: Cognition as Assessed by the Rex Complex Figure Test (RCFT), Delayed Recall
primary_outcome.description: The test measures recognition memory for the elements of the Rey complex figure, and assesses the respondent's ability to use cues to retrieve information after 25-30 minutes. Scoring of drawings is based on the widely used 36-point scoring system. Each of the 18 scoring units is scored based on accuracy and placement criteria. Items of the figure can earn points: Correct Image: placed properly (2 points), placed poorly (1 point) Distorted or Incomplete Image, but recognizable: placed properly (1 point), placed poorly (1/2) point Absent or not recognizable: 0 points Scale ranges 0-36, with 36 representing maximum cognition .

primary_outcome.measure: Sexual Function as Assessed by the Watts Sexual Function Questionnaire (WSFQ), Total Score
primary_outcome.description: The WSFQ contains 17 items that assess the domains of sexual desire/libido (6 items), arousal (1 item), orgasm/erectile function (7 items), and satisfaction(3 items). A five-point Likert-type scale ranging from "always" to "never" is used to generate a total score and four domain scores. The possible range of total sexual function scores is 17 to 85. Higher scores indicate better sexual function.

primary_outcome.measure: Sexual Function as Assessed by the Watts Sexual Function Questionnaire (WSFQ), Libido
primary_outcome.description: The domain of sexual desire/libido consists of 6 items. A five-point Likert-type scale ranging from "always" to "never" is used to generate a score, ranging from 6-30. Higher scores indicate increased libido/sexual desire.

primary_outcome.measure: Sexual Function as Assessed by the Watts Sexual Function Questionnaire (WSFQ), Erectile Function
primary_outcome.description: The domain of erectile function/orgasm consists of 7 items. A five-point Likert-type scale ranging from "always" to "never" is used to generate a score, ranging from 7-35. Higher scores indicate increased erectile function/achievement of orgasm.

primary_outcome.measure: Sexual Function as Assessed by the Watts Sexual Function Questionnaire (WSFQ), Arousal
primary_outcome.description: The domains of arousal (1 item subscale of the WSFQ), is assessed using a five-point Likert-type scale ranging from "always" to "never" to generate the score for arousal. The higher the number (range 1-5), the more the participant is able to experience arousal.

primary_outcome.measure: Sexual Function as Assessed by the Watts Sexual Function Questionnaire (WSFQ), Sanctification
primary_outcome.description: The domains of satisfaction (3 items), is assessed using a five-point Likert-type scale ranging from "always" to "never" to generate the score, ranging from 3-15. The higher the number, the higher the level of satisfaction with sexual function.

primary_outcome.measure: Sexual Function as Assessed by the International Index of Erectile Function (IIEF) Questionnaire, Total Score
primary_outcome.description: IIEF Questionnaire is used for the clinical assessment of erectile dysfunction and treatment outcomes in clinical trials. A score of 0-5 is awarded to each of the 15 questions which refer to the past 4 weeks only. The questions are split into the 4 main domains of male sexual function: erectile function, orgasmic function, sexual desire and intercourse satisfaction. The total score ranges from 6-75 with 6 being minimal erectile function and 75 representing maximal erectile function.

primary_outcome.measure: Sexual Function as Assessed by the International Index of Erectile Function (IIEF) Questionnaire, Erectile Function
primary_outcome.description: IIEF Questionnaire is used for the clinical assessment of erectile dysfunction and treatment outcomes in clinical trials. Erectile function is one domain, making up 6 out of 15 questions. The score ranges from 1-30, with the lowest score representing minimal erectile function.

primary_outcome.measure: Sexual Function as Assessed by the International Index of Erectile Function (IIEF) Questionnaire, Intercourse Satisfaction
primary_outcome.description: IIEF Questionnaire is used for the clinical assessment of erectile dysfunction and treatment outcomes in clinical trials, one domain being satisfaction with intercourse. A score of 0-5 is awarded to each of the 3 questions which refer to the past 4 weeks only. The score rangers from 0-15, with a score of 0 indicating that no intercourse was attempted in the last 4 weeks, 1= almost or little to no sanctification, 15= very highly satisfied.

primary_outcome.measure: Sexual Function as Assessed by the International Index of Erectile Function (IIEF) Questionnaire, Orgasmic Function
primary_outcome.description: IIEF Questionnaire is used for the clinical assessment of erectile dysfunction and treatment outcomes in clinical trials, one domain being satisfaction with orgasm. A score of 0-5 is awarded to each of the 2 questions which refer to the past 4 weeks only. The score rangers from 1-10, with a score of 0 indicating that no sexual stimulation or intercourse was attempted in the last 4 weeks, 1= almost never or never ejaculated, 10= almost always or always

primary_outcome.measure: Sexual Function as Assessed by the International Index of Erectile Function (IIEF) Questionnaire, Sexual Desire
primary_outcome.description: IIEF Questionnaire is used for the clinical assessment of erectile dysfunction and treatment outcomes in clinical trials, one domain being sexual desire. A score of 0-5 is awarded to each of the 2 questions which refer to the past 4 weeks only. The score rangers from 2-10, with a score of 2 indicating very low or none at all, and 10 representing almost always/very high.

primary_outcome.measure: Sexual Function as Assessed by the International Index of Erectile Function (IIEF) Questionnaire, Overall Sexual Satisfaction
primary_outcome.description: IIEF Questionnaire is used for the clinical assessment of erectile dysfunction and treatment outcomes in clinical trials, one domain being sexual satisfaction. A score of 0-5 is awarded to each of the 2 questions which refer to the past 4 weeks only. The score rangers from 2-10, with a score of 2 indicating very dissatisfied and 10 being very satisfied.

primary_outcome.measure: Daytime Sleepiness as Assessed by Epworth Sleepiness Scale (ESS)
primary_outcome.description: The ESS is a self-administered questionnaire with 8 questions. Respondents are asked to rate, on a 4-point scale (0-3), their usual chances of dozing off or falling asleep while engaged in eight different activities. Most people engage in those activities at least occasionally, although not necessarily every day. The ESS score (the sum of 8 item scores, 0-3) can range from 0 to 24. The higher the ESS score, the higher that person's average sleep propensity in daily life (ASP), or their 'daytime sleepiness'.

primary_outcome.measure: Hot Flashes as Assessed by the Blatt-Kuppermann Index (Hot Flash Component)
primary_outcome.description: Hot flashes were assessed using symptom severity 0= none, slight=1, moderate=2, and severe = 3. Hot flashes have a weighting factor of 4 on the overall Blatt-Kuppermann index, making score ranges 0-12, with 12 being the most severe hot flashes.

primary_outcome.measure: Mental Health as Assessed by the Short Form 36 Questionnaire
primary_outcome.description: The SF-36 has eight scaled scores; the scores are weighted sums of the questions in each section. Scores range from 0 - 100 Lower scores = more disability, higher scores = less disability Sections: Vitality, Physical functioning, Bodily pain, General health perception, Physical role functioning, Emotional role functioning, Social role functioning, Mental health

primary_outcome.measure: Physical Health as Assessed by the Short Form 36 Questionnaire
primary_outcome.description: The SF-36 has eight scaled scores; the scores are weighted sums of the questions in each section. Scores range from 0 - 100 Lower scores = more disability, higher scores = less disability Sections: Vitality, Physical functioning, Bodily pain, General health perception, Physical role functioning, Emotional role functioning, Social role functioning, Mental health

primary_outcome.measure: Fatigue as Assessed by the Short Form 36 Questionnaire
primary_outcome.description: The SF-36 has eight scaled scores; the scores are weighted sums of the questions in each section. Scores range from 0 - 100 Lower scores = more disability, higher scores = less disability Sections: Vitality, Physical functioning, Bodily pain, General health perception, Physical role functioning, Emotional role functioning, Social role functioning, Mental health

primary_outcome.measure: Physical Functioning as Assessed by the Short Form 36 Questionnaire
primary_outcome.description: The SF-36 has eight scaled scores; the scores are weighted sums of the questions in each section. Scores range from 0 - 100 Lower scores = more disability, higher scores = less disability Sections: Vitality, Physical functioning, Bodily pain, General health perception, Physical role functioning, Emotional role functioning, Social role functioning, Mental health

primary_outcome.measure: Body Pain as Assessed by the Short Form 36 Questionnaire
primary_outcome.description: The SF-36 has eight scaled scores; the scores are weighted sums of the questions in each section. Scores range from 0 - 100 Lower scores = more disability, higher scores = less disability Sections: Vitality, Physical functioning, Bodily pain, General health perception, Physical role functioning, Emotional role functioning, Social role functioning, Mental health

primary_outcome.measure: General Health Perceptions as Assessed by the Short Form 36 Questionnaire
primary_outcome.description: The SF-36 has eight scaled scores; the scores are weighted sums of the questions in each section. Scores range from 0 - 100 Lower scores = more disability, higher scores = less disability Sections: Vitality, Physical functioning, Bodily pain, General health perception, Physical role functioning, Emotional role functioning, Social role functioning, Mental health

primary_outcome.measure: Role Limitations Due to Physical Health as Assessed by the Short Form 36 Questionnaire
primary_outcome.description: The SF-36 has eight scaled scores; the scores are weighted sums of the questions in each section. Scores range from 0 - 100 Lower scores = more disability, higher scores = less disability Sections: Vitality, Physical functioning, Bodily pain, General health perception, Physical role functioning, Emotional role functioning, Social role functioning, Mental health

primary_outcome.measure: Role Limitations Due to Emotional Role Functioning as Assessed by the Short Form 36 Questionnaire
primary_outcome.description: The SF-36 has eight scaled scores; the scores are weighted sums of the questions in each section. Scores range from 0 - 100 Lower scores = more disability, higher scores = less disability Sections: Vitality, Physical functioning, Bodily pain, General health perception, Physical role functioning, Emotional role functioning, Social role functioning, Mental health

primary_outcome.measure: Social Functioning Due to Emotional Role Functioning as Assessed by the Short Form 36 Questionnaire
primary_outcome.description: The SF-36 has eight scaled scores; the scores are weighted sums of the questions in each section. Scores range from 0 - 100 Lower scores = more disability, higher scores = less disability Sections: Vitality, Physical functioning, Bodily pain, General health perception, Physical role functioning, Emotional role functioning, Social role functioning, Mental health

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- men > or =21 with prostate CA and hypogonadism for at least 3 months
Exclusion Criteria:
- on growth promoting agents
- on appetite stimulating agents
- on Prednisone and others

facility.name: Johns Hopkins University Clinical Trials Unit

participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: 39 participants were enrolled in this study. 3 were not randomized due to failed screening on laboratory assessment, 2 because they withdrew due to personal reasons, and 1 because of dislike of the taste of the compound.

baseline.population: Baseline characteristics were only recorded for the 33 participants who completed the study.

measure.title: Age, Customized
Sex: Female, Male
Region of Enrollment

outcome.title: Cognitive Function as Assessed by the National Adult Reading Test (NART)
outcome.description: the NART estimates intelligence levels of English-speaking patients. It consists of 50 short words with irregular spelling or phonetic appearance which the participant must read and pronounce. The higher the score, the higher number of correct responses. Scores are 0-50.

measure.title: Cognitive Function as Assessed by the National Adult Reading Test (NART)
measure.description: the NART estimates intelligence levels of English-speaking patients. It consists of 50 short words with irregular spelling or phonetic appearance which the participant must read and pronounce. The higher the score, the higher number of correct responses. Scores are 0-50.

outcome.title: Cognitive Function as Assessed by the Hopkins Verbal Learning Test (HVLT), Total Recall Score
outcome.description: The test consists 12 nouns, four words each from one of three semantic categories (e.g., precious gems, articles of clothing, vegetables, etc.), to be learned over the course of three learning trials. Approximately 20–25 min later, a delayed recall trial and a recognition trial are completed. The delayed recall requires free recall of any words remembered. The recognition trial is composed of 24 words, including the 12 target words and 12 false-positives, 6 semantically related, & 6 semantically unrelated. When scoring the HVLT, the three learning trials are combined to calculate a total recall score (0-36); the delayed recall trial creates the delayed recall score ( -12) ; the retention (%) score (0-100%) is calculated by dividing the delayed recall trial by the higher of learning trial 2 or 3; and the recognition discrimination index is comprised by subtracting the total number of false positives from the total number of true positives. A higher score = higher cognition.

Approximately 20–25 min later, a delayed recall trial and a recognition trial are completed. The delayed recall requires free recall of any words remembered. The recognition trial is composed of 24 words, including the 12 target words and 12 false-positives, 6 semantically related, & 6 semantically unrelated. When scoring the HVLT, the three learning trials are combined to calculate a total recall score (0-36); the delayed recall trial creates the delayed recall score ( -12) ; the retention (%) score (0-100%) is calculated by dividing the delayed recall trial by the higher of learning trial 2 or 3; and the recognition discrimination index is comprised by subtracting the total number of false positives from the total number of true positives. A higher score = higher cognition.

outcome.title: Cognitive Function as Assessed by the F-A-S Test
outcome.description: The F-A-S Test, a subtest of the Neurosensory Center Comprehensive Examination for Aphasia (NCCEA), is a measure of phonemic word fluency, which is a type of verbal fluency. It assesses phonemic fluency by requesting an individual to orally produce as many words as possible that begin with the letters F, A, and S within a prescribed time frame (1 minute)

measure.title: Cognitive Function as Assessed by the F-A-S Test
measure.description: The F-A-S Test, a subtest of the Neurosensory Center Comprehensive Examination for Aphasia (NCCEA), is a measure of phonemic word fluency, which is a type of verbal fluency. It assesses phonemic fluency by requesting an individual to orally produce as many words as possible that begin with the letters F, A, and S within a prescribed time frame (1 minute)

outcome.title: Cognition as Assessed by the Grooved Pegboard Test (GPT) , Dominant Hand Time (Seconds)
outcome.description: The GPT assesses eye–hand coordination and motor speed and thus requires sensory motor integration and a high level of motor processing. The test apparatus consists of a square metal surface (10.1 cm2) with a 5 × 5 matrix of keyhole shaped holes in various orientations. The task requires the examinee to pick up the keyhole shaped peg (3 mm in diameter) individually from the well just above the 5 × 5 matrix of holes from left to right and top to bottom as quickly as possible using the dominant hand. Because the holes are in various orientations, examinees must manipulate each peg in their hand (usually between the index finger and thumb) so that the peg aligns with the orientation of the hole. A faster time, indicates greater cognitive functioning.

A faster time, indicates greater cognitive functioning.

outcome.description: The GPT assesses eye–hand coordination and motor speed and thus requires sensory motor integration and a high level of motor processing. The test apparatus consists of a square metal surface (10.1 cm2) with a 5 × 5 matrix of keyhole shaped holes in various orientations. The task requires the examinee to pick up the keyhole shaped peg (3 mm in diameter) individually from the well just above the 5 × 5 matrix of holes from left to right and top to bottom as quickly as possible using the dominant hand. Because the holes are in various orientations, examinees must manipulate each peg in their hand (usually between the index finger and thumb) so that the peg aligns with the orientation of the hole.

measure.title: Cognition as Assessed by the Grooved Pegboard Test (GPT) , Number of Non- Dominant Hand Drops
measure.description: The GPT assesses eye–hand coordination and motor speed and thus requires sensory motor integration and a high level of motor processing. The test apparatus consists of a square metal surface (10.1 cm2) with a 5 × 5 matrix of keyhole shaped holes in various orientations. The task requires the examinee to pick up the keyhole shaped peg (3 mm in diameter) individually from the well just above the 5 × 5 matrix of holes from left to right and top to bottom as quickly as possible using the dominant hand. Because the holes are in various orientations, examinees must manipulate each peg in their hand (usually between the index finger and thumb) so that the peg aligns with the orientation of the hole.

outcome.title: Cognition as Assessed by the Rex Complex Figure Test (RCFT), Immediate Recall
outcome.description: The test measures recognition memory for the elements of the Rey complex figure, and assesses the respondent’s ability to use cues to retrieve information. Scoring of drawings is based on the widely used 36-point scoring system. Each of the 18 scoring units is scored based on accuracy and placement criteria. Items of the figure can earn points: Correct Image: placed properly (2 points), placed poorly (1 point) Distorted or Incomplete Image, but recognizable: placed properly (1 point), placed poorly (1/2) point Absent or not recognizable: 0 points Scale ranges 0-36. with 36 being greatest cognitive function.

measure.title: Cognition as Assessed by the Rex Complex Figure Test (RCFT), Immediate Recall
measure.description: The test measures recognition memory for the elements of the Rey complex figure, and assesses the respondent’s ability to use cues to retrieve information. Scoring of drawings is based on the widely used 36-point scoring system. Each of the 18 scoring units is scored based on accuracy and placement criteria. Items of the figure can earn points: Correct Image: placed properly (2 points), placed poorly (1 point) Distorted or Incomplete Image, but recognizable: placed properly (1 point), placed poorly (1/2) point Absent or not recognizable: 0 points Scale ranges 0-36. with 36 being greatest cognitive function.

outcome.title: Cognition as Assessed by the Rex Complex Figure Test (RCFT), Delayed Recall
outcome.description: The test measures recognition memory for the elements of the Rey complex figure, and assesses the respondent’s ability to use cues to retrieve information after 25-30 minutes. Scoring of drawings is based on the widely used 36-point scoring system. Each of the 18 scoring units is scored based on accuracy and placement criteria. Items of the figure can earn points: Correct Image: placed properly (2 points), placed poorly (1 point) Distorted or Incomplete Image, but recognizable: placed properly (1 point), placed poorly (1/2) point Absent or not recognizable: 0 points Scale ranges 0-36, with 36 representing maximum cognition .

measure.title: Cognition as Assessed by the Rex Complex Figure Test (RCFT), Delayed Recall
measure.description: The test measures recognition memory for the elements of the Rey complex figure, and assesses the respondent’s ability to use cues to retrieve information after 25-30 minutes. Scoring of drawings is based on the widely used 36-point scoring system. Each of the 18 scoring units is scored based on accuracy and placement criteria. Items of the figure can earn points: Correct Image: placed properly (2 points), placed poorly (1 point) Distorted or Incomplete Image, but recognizable: placed properly (1 point), placed poorly (1/2) point Absent or not recognizable: 0 points Scale ranges 0-36, with 36 representing maximum cognition .

outcome.title: Sexual Function as Assessed by the Watts Sexual Function Questionnaire (WSFQ), Total Score
outcome.description: The WSFQ contains 17 items that assess the domains of sexual desire/libido (6 items), arousal (1 item), orgasm/erectile function (7 items), and satisfaction(3 items). A five-point Likert-type scale ranging from “always” to “never” is used to generate a total score and four domain scores. The possible range of total sexual function scores is 17 to 85. Higher scores indicate better sexual function.

measure.title: Sexual Function as Assessed by the Watts Sexual Function Questionnaire (WSFQ), Total Score
measure.description: The WSFQ contains 17 items that assess the domains of sexual desire/libido (6 items), arousal (1 item), orgasm/erectile function (7 items), and satisfaction(3 items). A five-point Likert-type scale ranging from “always” to “never” is used to generate a total score and four domain scores. The possible range of total sexual function scores is 17 to 85. Higher scores indicate better sexual function.

outcome.title: Sexual Function as Assessed by the Watts Sexual Function Questionnaire (WSFQ), Libido
outcome.description: The domain of sexual desire/libido consists of 6 items. A five-point Likert-type scale ranging from “always” to “never” is used to generate a score, ranging from 6-30. Higher scores indicate increased libido/sexual desire.

measure.title: Sexual Function as Assessed by the Watts Sexual Function Questionnaire (WSFQ), Libido
measure.description: The domain of sexual desire/libido consists of 6 items. A five-point Likert-type scale ranging from “always” to “never” is used to generate a score, ranging from 6-30. Higher scores indicate increased libido/sexual desire.

outcome.title: Sexual Function as Assessed by the Watts Sexual Function Questionnaire (WSFQ), Erectile Function
outcome.description: The domain of erectile function/orgasm consists of 7 items. A five-point Likert-type scale ranging from “always” to “never” is used to generate a score, ranging from 7-35. Higher scores indicate increased erectile function/achievement of orgasm.

measure.title: Sexual Function as Assessed by the Watts Sexual Function Questionnaire (WSFQ), Erectile Function
measure.description: The domain of erectile function/orgasm consists of 7 items. A five-point Likert-type scale ranging from “always” to “never” is used to generate a score, ranging from 7-35. Higher scores indicate increased erectile function/achievement of orgasm.

outcome.title: Sexual Function as Assessed by the Watts Sexual Function Questionnaire (WSFQ), Arousal
outcome.description: The domains of arousal (1 item subscale of the WSFQ), is assessed using a five-point Likert-type scale ranging from “always” to “never” to generate the score for arousal. The higher the number (range 1-5), the more the participant is able to experience arousal.

measure.title: Sexual Function as Assessed by the Watts Sexual Function Questionnaire (WSFQ), Arousal
measure.description: The domains of arousal (1 item subscale of the WSFQ), is assessed using a five-point Likert-type scale ranging from “always” to “never” to generate the score for arousal. The higher the number (range 1-5), the more the participant is able to experience arousal.

outcome.title: Sexual Function as Assessed by the Watts Sexual Function Questionnaire (WSFQ), Sanctification
outcome.description: The domains of satisfaction (3 items), is assessed using a five-point Likert-type scale ranging from “always” to “never” to generate the score, ranging from 3-15. The higher the number, the higher the level of satisfaction with sexual function.

measure.title: Sexual Function as Assessed by the Watts Sexual Function Questionnaire (WSFQ), Sanctification
measure.description: The domains of satisfaction (3 items), is assessed using a five-point Likert-type scale ranging from “always” to “never” to generate the score, ranging from 3-15. The higher the number, the higher the level of satisfaction with sexual function.

outcome.title: Sexual Function as Assessed by the International Index of Erectile Function (IIEF) Questionnaire, Total Score
outcome.description: IIEF Questionnaire is used for the clinical assessment of erectile dysfunction and treatment outcomes in clinical trials. A score of 0-5 is awarded to each of the 15 questions which refer to the past 4 weeks only. The questions are split into the 4 main domains of male sexual function: erectile function, orgasmic function, sexual desire and intercourse satisfaction. The total score ranges from 6-75 with 6 being minimal erectile function and 75 representing maximal erectile function.

measure.title: Sexual Function as Assessed by the International Index of Erectile Function (IIEF) Questionnaire, Total Score
measure.description: IIEF Questionnaire is used for the clinical assessment of erectile dysfunction and treatment outcomes in clinical trials. A score of 0-5 is awarded to each of the 15 questions which refer to the past 4 weeks only. The questions are split into the 4 main domains of male sexual function: erectile function, orgasmic function, sexual desire and intercourse satisfaction. The total score ranges from 6-75 with 6 being minimal erectile function and 75 representing maximal erectile function.

outcome.title: Sexual Function as Assessed by the International Index of Erectile Function (IIEF) Questionnaire, Erectile Function
outcome.description: IIEF Questionnaire is used for the clinical assessment of erectile dysfunction and treatment outcomes in clinical trials. Erectile function is one domain, making up 6 out of 15 questions. The score ranges from 1-30, with the lowest score representing minimal erectile function.

measure.title: Sexual Function as Assessed by the International Index of Erectile Function (IIEF) Questionnaire, Erectile Function
measure.description: IIEF Questionnaire is used for the clinical assessment of erectile dysfunction and treatment outcomes in clinical trials. Erectile function is one domain, making up 6 out of 15 questions. The score ranges from 1-30, with the lowest score representing minimal erectile function.

outcome.title: Sexual Function as Assessed by the International Index of Erectile Function (IIEF) Questionnaire, Intercourse Satisfaction
outcome.description: IIEF Questionnaire is used for the clinical assessment of erectile dysfunction and treatment outcomes in clinical trials, one domain being satisfaction with intercourse. A score of 0-5 is awarded to each of the 3 questions which refer to the past 4 weeks only. The score rangers from 0-15, with a score of 0 indicating that no intercourse was attempted in the last 4 weeks, 1= almost or little to no sanctification, 15= very highly satisfied.

measure.title: Sexual Function as Assessed by the International Index of Erectile Function (IIEF) Questionnaire, Intercourse Satisfaction
measure.description: IIEF Questionnaire is used for the clinical assessment of erectile dysfunction and treatment outcomes in clinical trials, one domain being satisfaction with intercourse. A score of 0-5 is awarded to each of the 3 questions which refer to the past 4 weeks only. The score rangers from 0-15, with a score of 0 indicating that no intercourse was attempted in the last 4 weeks, 1= almost or little to no sanctification, 15= very highly satisfied.

outcome.title: Sexual Function as Assessed by the International Index of Erectile Function (IIEF) Questionnaire, Orgasmic Function
outcome.description: IIEF Questionnaire is used for the clinical assessment of erectile dysfunction and treatment outcomes in clinical trials, one domain being satisfaction with orgasm. A score of 0-5 is awarded to each of the 2 questions which refer to the past 4 weeks only. The score rangers from 1-10, with a score of 0 indicating that no sexual stimulation or intercourse was attempted in the last 4 weeks, 1= almost never or never ejaculated, 10= almost always or always

measure.title: Sexual Function as Assessed by the International Index of Erectile Function (IIEF) Questionnaire, Orgasmic Function
measure.description: IIEF Questionnaire is used for the clinical assessment of erectile dysfunction and treatment outcomes in clinical trials, one domain being satisfaction with orgasm. A score of 0-5 is awarded to each of the 2 questions which refer to the past 4 weeks only. The score rangers from 1-10, with a score of 0 indicating that no sexual stimulation or intercourse was attempted in the last 4 weeks, 1= almost never or never ejaculated, 10= almost always or always

outcome.title: Sexual Function as Assessed by the International Index of Erectile Function (IIEF) Questionnaire, Sexual Desire
outcome.description: IIEF Questionnaire is used for the clinical assessment of erectile dysfunction and treatment outcomes in clinical trials, one domain being sexual desire. A score of 0-5 is awarded to each of the 2 questions which refer to the past 4 weeks only. The score rangers from 2-10, with a score of 2 indicating very low or none at all, and 10 representing almost always/very high.

measure.title: Sexual Function as Assessed by the International Index of Erectile Function (IIEF) Questionnaire, Sexual Desire
measure.description: IIEF Questionnaire is used for the clinical assessment of erectile dysfunction and treatment outcomes in clinical trials, one domain being sexual desire. A score of 0-5 is awarded to each of the 2 questions which refer to the past 4 weeks only. The score rangers from 2-10, with a score of 2 indicating very low or none at all, and 10 representing almost always/very high.

outcome.title: Sexual Function as Assessed by the International Index of Erectile Function (IIEF) Questionnaire, Overall Sexual Satisfaction
outcome.description: IIEF Questionnaire is used for the clinical assessment of erectile dysfunction and treatment outcomes in clinical trials, one domain being sexual satisfaction. A score of 0-5 is awarded to each of the 2 questions which refer to the past 4 weeks only. The score rangers from 2-10, with a score of 2 indicating very dissatisfied and 10 being very satisfied.

measure.title: Sexual Function as Assessed by the International Index of Erectile Function (IIEF) Questionnaire, Overall Sexual Satisfaction
measure.description: IIEF Questionnaire is used for the clinical assessment of erectile dysfunction and treatment outcomes in clinical trials, one domain being sexual satisfaction. A score of 0-5 is awarded to each of the 2 questions which refer to the past 4 weeks only. The score rangers from 2-10, with a score of 2 indicating very dissatisfied and 10 being very satisfied.

outcome.title: Daytime Sleepiness as Assessed by Epworth Sleepiness Scale (ESS)
outcome.description: The ESS is a self-administered questionnaire with 8 questions. Respondents are asked to rate, on a 4-point scale (0-3), their usual chances of dozing off or falling asleep while engaged in eight different activities. Most people engage in those activities at least occasionally, although not necessarily every day. The ESS score (the sum of 8 item scores, 0-3) can range from 0 to 24. The higher the ESS score, the higher that person’s average sleep propensity in daily life (ASP), or their ‘daytime sleepiness’.

measure.title: Daytime Sleepiness as Assessed by Epworth Sleepiness Scale (ESS)
measure.description: The ESS is a self-administered questionnaire with 8 questions. Respondents are asked to rate, on a 4-point scale (0-3), their usual chances of dozing off or falling asleep while engaged in eight different activities. Most people engage in those activities at least occasionally, although not necessarily every day. The ESS score (the sum of 8 item scores, 0-3) can range from 0 to 24. The higher the ESS score, the higher that person’s average sleep propensity in daily life (ASP), or their ‘daytime sleepiness’.

outcome.title: Hot Flashes as Assessed by the Blatt-Kuppermann Index (Hot Flash Component)
outcome.description: Hot flashes were assessed using symptom severity 0= none, slight=1, moderate=2, and severe = 3. Hot flashes have a weighting factor of 4 on the overall Blatt-Kuppermann index, making score ranges 0-12, with 12 being the most severe hot flashes.

measure.title: Hot Flashes as Assessed by the Blatt-Kuppermann Index (Hot Flash Component)
measure.description: Hot flashes were assessed using symptom severity 0= none, slight=1, moderate=2, and severe = 3. Hot flashes have a weighting factor of 4 on the overall Blatt-Kuppermann index, making score ranges 0-12, with 12 being the most severe hot flashes.

outcome.title: Mental Health as Assessed by the Short Form 36 Questionnaire
outcome.description: The SF-36 has eight scaled scores; the scores are weighted sums of the questions in each section. Scores range from 0 - 100 Lower scores = more disability, higher scores = less disability Sections: Vitality, Physical functioning, Bodily pain, General health perception, Physical role functioning, Emotional role functioning, Social role functioning, Mental health

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
